thread.title: H.S. boys soccer: Pascack Valley stuns Bergen Catholic - Boys Soccer
thread.title_full: H.S. boys soccer: Pascack Valley stuns Bergen Catholic - Boys Soccer - NorthJersey.com

author: JIM HAGUE
title: H.S. boys soccer: Pascack Valley stuns Bergen Catholic - Boys Soccer
text:
RAMSEY â€“ Roy Nygren has enjoyed nearly 400 wins during his storied coaching career in boys soccer, but none are more memorable than the one his Pascack Valley squad earned Sunday at the Bergen County tournament quarterfinals Sunday afternoon.
The Indians pulled off the upset of upsets, knocking off top-seeded Bergen Catholic, 3-2, on a goal from Mike Lin two minutes into the second overtime, causing Nygren to sprint across the field in joy, totally forgetting about his advanced age.
"This is tremendous," Nygren said after the goal. "This one is in the top 10 of all-time games."
The Indians will face Ramapo in the semifinals on Saturday at Indian Hills. Ramapo defeated Don Bosco in the other quarterfinal, 1-0.
Indians goalkeeper Josh Ulin, who gave a heroic performance with an astounding 18 saves, believes that the Indians are playing with pure emotion.
Ulin's friend and classmate, Zack Latteri, died in July after a 5 1/2-year battle with leukemia.
"I play for Zack every single day," Ulin said. "He's my motivation for everything. If he could stay strong through all he's been through, then we could all benefit from it."
Lin agreed.
"Everyone thinks of Zack every time we play," said Lin, who knocked home a direct free kick from about 30 yards out. "My teammates all wanted me to take the kick. Once I hit it, I knew it was in."
"Mike Lin is a tremendous player for us," Nygren said. "He showed a lot of courage today, because he was playing with an injured leg. He just curled that shot to the back of the net and that was it."
Lin's shot sent Bergen Catholic (9-1-2) to defeat for the first time this season.
"I think this is extremely disappointing, because we played a tremendous game of soccer," Bergen Catholic head coach Pete Berkanish said. "We controlled a good portion of the game. When you come out on the negative side, it hurts tremendously."
The Crusaders held a commanding 21-6 advantage in shots on goal, yet couldn't collect the victory over the Indians (9-3).
